revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2008}} A '''creature of statute''' (also known as '''creature of the state''') is a legal entity, such as a [[corporation]], created by [[statute]]. Creatures of statute may include [[Municipality|municipalities]] and other artificial legal entities or relationships.<ref name="quaqua1">{{cite web |url=http://www.quaqua.org/creature.htm |title=Creature of the State |website=Quaqua Society}}</ref> Thus, when a statute in some fashion requires the formation of a corporate body—often for governmental purposes—such bodies when formed are known as "creatures of statute." The same concept is also expressed with the phrase "creature of the state."<ref name="quaqua1"/>
The term "creature of statute" is most common to the [[United States]]. In the [[United Kingdom]], these bodies are simply called [[statutory corporation]]s (or statutory bodies) and generally have some governmental function. The [[United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority]] is an example. In a wider sense, most companies in the UK are created under statute since the [[Companies Act 1985]] specifies how a company may be created by a member of the public, but these companies are not called 'statutory corporations'. Often, in American legal and business documents that speak of governing bodies (''e.g.'', a board that governs small businesses in China) these bodies are described as "creatures of statute" to inform readers of their origins and format although the national governments that created them may not term them as creatures of statute. [[Australia]] also uses the term "creature of statute" to describe some governmental bodies.
The importance of a corporate body, regardless of its exact function, when such a body is a creature of statute is that its active functions can only be within the scope detailed by the statute which created that corporation. Thereby, the creature of statute is the tangible manifestation of the functions or work described by a given statute. The jurisdiction of a body that is a creature of statute is also therefore limited to the functional scope written into the laws that created that body. Unlike most (private) corporate bodies, creatures of statute cannot expand their business interests into other diverse areas.
==See also== * [[Competition regulator]] * [[Statutory authority]] * [[Regulatory agency]] * [[Independent agencies of the United States government]] * [[Public-benefit corporation]] * [[Quango]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

{{unreferenced|date=May 2014}} [[File:Dekret kutnohorský.jpg|thumb|270px|Decree of Kutná Hora, deed issued on 18 September 1418 for Jan Hus]] The '''Decree of Kutná Hora''' ({{lang-cs|Dekret Kutnohorský}}) or '''Decree of Kuttenberg''' ({{lang-de|Kuttenberger Dekret}}) was issued on 18 January 1409 in [[Kutná Hora]] (''Kuttenberg''), [[Kingdom of Bohemia|Bohemia]] by King [[Wenceslaus IV of Bohemia|Wenceslaus IV]] to give members of the [[Lands of the Bohemian Crown|Bohemian]] [[Nation (university)|nation]] a decisive voice in the affairs of the [[Charles University]] in [[Prague]].
Since the university was founded by King [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles IV]] in 1348, the ''[[studium generale]]'' was divided among Bohemian (including [[German language|German]]-speaking citizens), [[Duchy of Bavaria|Bavarian]], [[Electorate of Saxony|Saxon]], and [[Kingdom of Poland (1385–1569)|Polish]] "nations". From 1403 onwards, the religious [[Lollardy|Lollard movement]] and the doctrines of the [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] theologian [[John Wycliffe]] led to controversy at the Prague University. The Bohemian reformers around [[Jan Hus]] wanted to teach this new doctrine, but most [[Kingdom of Germany|German]] masters and professors voted against the new "[[Heresy|heretic]]" thinking. [[File:Auszug aus Prag 1409.jpg|thumb|left|German students leaving Prague for Leipzig (postcard, {{circa|1909}})]] In anticipation of the [[Council of Pisa]], the three "foreign" nations (Poland, Bavaria and Saxony) at the university opposed the request of Wenceslaus to take a neutral attitude between the two rival popes in the [[Western Schism]]. Wenceslaus himself hoped for support of a new Pope to regain the [[King of the Romans|German kingship]] after his deposition by [[Rupert, King of Germany|Rupert of the Palatinate]] nine years before. However, King Rupert, relying on the support of [[Pope Gregory XII]] and the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Prague|Prague]] archbishop [[Zbyněk Zajíc of Hazmburk]], pressured German teachers and students not to side with his Bohemian rival.
A delegation led by [[Jerome of Prague]] went to Wenceslaus' court staying at the [[Royal cities|royal city]] of Kutná Hora (according to other sources at [[Točník Castle]]), where the king promised to change the constitution of the university. On 18 January 1409, he had the statutes amended: with his decree, he gave the Bohemian nation three votes and one vote each to the other three nations. Shortly after that, Hus himself became rector of the university, succeeding [[Johannes Hoffmann von Schweidnitz]]. As another result of the Decree of Kutná Hora, numerous German academics (about 80 percent of the teaching staff) and their students left the university. This exodus resulted in the foundation of the [[University of Leipzig]] in [[Margravate of Meissen|Meissen]], among others, and led to a considerable isolation of the Prague university. In 1417 the university officially adopted the [[Hussites|Hussite]] confession and henceforth, [[Utraquism|Utraquist]] scholars taught and studied here. The rising influence of this doctrine and the execution of Jan Hus in 1415 culminated in the outbreak of the [[Hussite Wars]].
== External links == *[http://www.ceskaliteratura.cz/dok/dekret.htm Decree of Kutná Hora wording {{cs icon}}]

page.title: Decriminalization of non-medical cannabis in the United States

revision.comment: /* Decriminalization efforts materialize (1970s) */ adjust wording
revision.text:
{{Main|Cannabis in the United States}} {{Legality of cannabis by US state}}
In the [[United States]], the [[Recreational drug use|non-medical]] use of [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] is decriminalized in 13 states (plus the [[U.S. Virgin Islands]]), and legalized in another 10 states (plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] and [[Northern Mariana Islands]]), as of November 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=MARIJUANA OVERVIEW|url=http://www.ncsl.org/research/civil-and-criminal-justice/marijuana-overview.aspx|website=National Conference of State Legislatures|accessdate=January 23, 2018}}</ref> "Decriminalization" refers to a policy of reduced penalties for cannabis offenses, typically involving a [[civil penalty]] for possession of small amounts (similar to how a minor traffic violation is treated), instead of criminal prosecution or the threat of arrest.<ref>{{cite web|title=Marijuana Legalization and Decriminalization Overview|url=http://criminal.findlaw.com/criminal-charges/marijuana-legalization-and-decriminalization-overview.html|website=FindLaw|accessdate=January 23, 2018}}</ref><ref name="cannalawblog">{{cite news|title=Marijuana Decriminalization Versus Legalization: A Difference That Matters|url=https://www.cannalawblog.com/marijuana-decriminalization-versus-legalization-cause-it-matters/|accessdate=January 23, 2018|work=Canna Law Blog|date=July 1, 2014}}</ref> In jurisdictions without any penalties the policy is referred to as legalization, although the term decriminalization is sometimes broadly used for this purpose as well.<ref name="cannalawblog" />
The movement to decriminalize cannabis in the U.S. emerged during the 1970s, when a total of 11 states decriminalized (beginning with [[Oregon]] in 1973). The findings of the 1972 [[Shafer Commission]] helped provide momentum to these efforts, as did the 1976 election of [[Presidency of Jimmy Carter|President Jimmy Carter]] (who spoke in favor of decriminalization and endorsed legislation to federally decriminalize). By the end of the decade the tide had turned strongly in the other direction, however, and no state would decriminalize again until 2001.
Efforts to legalize cannabis in the U.S. included a number of ballot initiatives leading up to 2012, but none succeeded. In 2012, success was finally achieved when [[Washington (state)|Washington]] and [[Colorado]] became the first two states to legalize. In 2014 and 2016 several more states followed, and in 2018 [[Vermont]] became the first to legalize through an act of state legislature. All jurisdictions that have legalized allow for the commercial distribution of cannabis, except Vermont and the District of Columbia. All allow for personal cultivation, except Washington state.
At the federal level, cannabis remains prohibited for any use under the [[Controlled Substances Act]] of 1970. The [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] has generally not enforced federal law in states that have legalized cannabis, under the guidance of the [[Cole Memorandum]] that was adopted in August 2013. In January 2018, however, the Cole memo was rescinded by Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]], granting [[United States Attorney|U.S. Attorneys]] greater authority to enforce federal law.
==Early use and criminalization == Cannabis was popularized in the U.S. around the mid-19th century, used mostly for its therapeutic benefits in the treatment of a wide range of medical conditions.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Marijuana as Medicine - 2900 BC to Present|url=http://medicalmarijuana.procon.org/view.timeline.php?timelineID=000026|website=ProCon.org|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}</ref> Its use as medicine continued into the 20th century, but declined somewhat due to a number of different factors.<ref>{{citation|last1=Grinspoon|first1=Lester|title=History of Cannabis as a Medicine|date=August 16, 2005|url=http://www.maps.org/research-archive/mmj/grinspoon_history_cannabis_medicine.pdf}}</ref> The recreational use of cannabis began to emerge in the early 20th century, introduced to the U.S. by Mexicans fleeing the dictatorship of President [[Porfirio Díaz]].<ref name="Dufton">{{cite book|last1=Dufton|first1=Emily|title=Grass Roots: The Rise and Fall and Rise of Marijuana in America|date=December 5, 2017|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0465096169}}</ref> As its use spread north of the border, cannabis became stigmatized due to strong anti-Mexican sentiments that had taken hold.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McDonald|first1=David|title=The Racist Roots of Marijuana Prohibition|url=https://fee.org/articles/the-racist-roots-of-marijuana-prohibition/|accessdate=January 31, 2018|work=Foundation for Economic Freedom|date=April 11, 2017}}</ref>
By 1936, the non-medical use of cannabis had been banned in every state.<ref name="Booth history">{{cite book|last1=Booth|first1=Martin|title=Cannabis: A History|date=June 2005|publisher=St. Martin's Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0-312-42494-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=O7AoY6ljSygC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> Cannabis was then effectively outlawed at the federal level, following the passage of the [[Marihuana Tax Act of 1937]].<ref name="tax act">{{cite news|last1=Glick|first1=Daniel|title=80 Years Ago This Week, Marijuana Prohibition Began With These Arrests|url=https://www.leafly.com/news/politics/drug-war-prisoners-1-2-true-story-moses-sam-two-denver-drifters-became-cannabis-pioneers|accessdate=January 31, 2018|work=Leafly|date=December 2016}}</ref> Cannabis remained mostly an underground drug until the 1960s, when it found widespread popularity among large numbers of young people and [[hippie]]s, and was used commonly at protests against the Vietnam War.<ref name="Dufton" /> Cannabis was officially banned for any use (medical included) with the passage of the [[Controlled Substances Act]] of 1970, following [[Leary v. United States|a constitutional challenge]] to the Marihuana Tax Act of 1937.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tayag|first1=Yasmin|title=Timothy Leary's Arrest For Marijuana Possession Still Matters 50 Years Later|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/12782-timothy-leary-s-arrest-for-marijuana-possession-still-matters-50-years-later|accessdate=February 27, 2018|work=Inverse|date=March 13, 2016}}</ref>
==History of decriminalization== ===Supporters of reform begin to organize (1964)=== The movement to legalize cannabis in the U.S. was sparked by the 1964 arrest of {{vanchor|Lowell Eggemeier}}, a [[San Francisco]] man who walked into the city's Hall of Justice and lit up a joint, requesting to be arrested.<ref name="Lee">{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Martin A.|title=Smoke Signals: A Social History of Marijuana – Medical, Recreational, and Scientific|date=August 2012|publisher=Scribner|location=New York|isbn=978-1439102602}}</ref> As it was a felony to use cannabis in California, Eggemeier was quickly hauled off to prison, where he was held for close to a year.<ref name="Dufton" /> Eggemeier was defended by attorney James R. White, who had never worked on a drug case before nor was he much familiar with cannabis, but took interest in the matter as a devoted civil libertarian (describing himself as "to the right of [[Barry Goldwater]]").<ref name="Lee" /> While researching the case, White became a strong proponent for the legalization of cannabis, and went on to found LEMAR (shortened version of LEgalize MARijuana) in December 1964.<ref name="Dufton" /> LEMAR was the first organization in the U.S. dedicated to ending cannabis prohibition.<ref name="Heddleston">{{cite thesis|last1=Heddleston|first1=Thomas R.|title=From the Frontlines to the Bottom Line: Medical Marijuana, the War on Drugs, and the Drug Policy Reform Movement|url=http://escholarship.org/uc/item/1t7220hj|publisher=UC Santa Cruz Electronic Theses and Dissertations|date=June 2012|archive-url=https://archive.org/details/MedicalMarijuanaTheWarOnDrugsAndTheDrugPolicyReformMovement|archive-date=February 16, 2014|dead-url=no}}</ref>
Among those in attendance at the first LEMAR rally was poet [[Allen Ginsberg]], who was staying in [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]] at the time.<ref name="Lee" /> Upon returning home to New York City he founded the first East Coast chapter of LEMAR.<ref name="Dufton" /> Ginsberg's activism and writings helped inspire the founding of other LEMAR chapters, including a [[Detroit]] chapter by fellow poet [[John Sinclair (poet)|John Sinclair]].<ref name="Lee" /> Similar groups advocating for legalization formed across the country in the ensuing years.<ref name="Dufton" />
By 1971, two main groups supporting cannabis reform had emerged – Amorphia based in San Francisco (founded by Blair Newman) and the [[National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws]] (NORML) based in Washington, D.C.<ref name="Dufton" /> NORML was founded by [[Keith Stroup]], an attorney who had previously worked as a researcher for [[Ralph Nader]]'s National Commission on Product Safety.<ref name="Dufton" /> Drawing upon his experience working with Nader (and his consumer advocate devotees "Nader's Raiders"), Stroup sought to create a consumer advocacy group dedicated to protecting cannabis consumers.<ref name="Heddleston" /> He founded NORML in 1970, with the aim of adopting a more professionalized manner of advocacy than other cannabis reform groups (such as Amorphia) more closely associated with the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|counterculture]].<ref name="Dufton" /> Eventually Amorphia was merged into NORML as it ran into financial difficulties, becoming the California chapter of NORML in 1974.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Mission|url=http://www.canorml.org/canormlmission.html|website=California NORML|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}</ref>
===Shafer Commission (1972)=== As part of the Controlled Substances Act of 1970, a commission was formed to study the rising use of cannabis in America, and advise to the president and Congress a set of policy recommendations. [[Presidency of Richard Nixon|President Nixon]] appointed several members of the commission himself, including former Pennsylvania governor [[Raymond P. Shafer]] (who was a former prosecutor with a tough "law and order" reputation) to serve as chairman.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Zeese|first1=Kevin|title=Once-Secret "Nixon Tapes" Show Why the U.S. Outlawed Pot|url=http://www.alternet.org/story/12666/once-secret_%22nixon_tapes%22_show_why_the_u.s._outlawed_pot|accessdate=January 13, 2018|work=AlterNet|date=March 20, 2002}}</ref> Nixon made it known to Shafer that he strongly opposed the legalization of cannabis, and he advised Shafer to "keep your commission in line" months before the final report was issued.<ref>{{citation|title=Nixon Tapes Show Roots of Marijuana Prohibition: Misinformation, Culture Wars and Prejudice|url=http://www.csdp.org/research/shafernixon.pdf|work=Common Sense for Drug Policy|date=March 2002}}</ref> The release of the 1184-page report would not be to Nixon's liking, however, as the [[Shafer Commission]] concluded in March 1972 that cannabis was a relatively benign drug whose dangers had been exaggerated.<ref name="Dufton" /> The report also concluded that harsh laws against cannabis did more harm than good, and recommended that criminal penalties be removed for possession and distribution of small amounts of the drug.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gardner|first1=Fred|title=How Nixon Destroyed the Evidence on Marijuana|url=https://www.marijuana.com/news/2014/08/richard-nixon-was-the-marijuana-antichrist/|accessdate=January 13, 2018|work=marijuana.com|date=August 5, 2014}}</ref> Nixon firmly rejected the results of the commission,<ref name="Dufton" /> while proponents of reform used the findings to their advantage, frequently citing the report to build support for decriminalizing cannabis in subsequent years.<ref name="Heddleston" />
===Decriminalization efforts materialize (1970s)=== During the early 1970s, legislative efforts to reform cannabis laws began to materialize. Among these was a 1972 ballot measure seeking to legalize cannabis in California, spearheaded by the group Amorphia.<ref name="sinclair">{{cite news|last1=Sinclair|first1=John|title=Getting NORML -- A brief history of the movement to legalize marijuana|url=https://www.metrotimes.com/detroit/getting-norml/Content?oid=2150635|accessdate=January 24, 2018|work=Detroit Metro Times|date=October 27, 2010}}</ref> [[California Proposition 19 (1972)|Proposition 19]] – the California Marijuana Initiative – ultimately failed with 33% of the vote.<ref name="Heddleston" /> Although it was defeated by a wide margin, supporters of the initiative were encouraged by the results,<ref name="sinclair" /> which provided momentum to other reform efforts in California throughout the decade.<ref name="Heddleston" />
In 1973 [[Oregon]] became the first state to decriminalize cannabis, reducing the penalty for up to one ounce to a $100 fine.<ref name="Heddleston" /> Other states were reluctant to follow, however, in part due to influence from the Nixon administration which staunchly opposed such reforms.<ref name="Dufton" /> Decriminalization efforts were bolstered by Nixon's resignation in August 1974, however, ushering in the [[Presidency of Gerald Ford|Ford administration]] and a more tolerant view toward cannabis from the White House.<ref name="Dufton" /> The November 1974 election also brought a wave of new Democrats to state legislatures across the country.<ref name="Anderson">{{cite book|last1=Anderson|first1=Patrick|title=High In America: The True Story Behind NORML And The Politics Of Marijuana|date=February 27, 1981|publisher=The Viking Press|isbn=978-0670119905|url=http://www.druglibrary.org/special/anderson/highinamerica.htm}}</ref>
In 1975 a federal committee examined the use of cannabis and other drugs in America, building upon the findings of the Shafer Commission three years earlier.<ref name="Dufton" /> Although the committee – the Domestic Council Drug Abuse Task Force – did not advocate decriminalization outright, it did recommend that attention be shifted to more harmful drugs (such as [[heroin]]), and concluded that cannabis was the "least serious" drug problem facing the nation.<ref name="Dufton" /> Also in 1975, congressional hearings were held on decriminalizing cannabis for the first time.<ref name="Dufton" /> As these developments provided momentum to reform efforts, a total of five more states ([[Alaska]], [[Maine]], [[Colorado]], [[California]], and [[Ohio]]) decriminalized cannabis in 1975.<ref name="Anderson" />
Shortly after Alaska decriminalized in 1975, a ruling by the Supreme Court of Alaska effectively legalized cannabis in the state, in the case ''[[Ravin v. State]]''.<ref name="Anderson" /> The ruling stemmed from the 1972 arrest of Irwin Ravin, an Alaska resident who allowed himself to be caught possessing cannabis in order to challenge state law.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burke|first1=Jill|title=Irwin Ravin, Alaska marijuana rights activist, dies|url=https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/article/irwin-ravin-alaska-marijuana-rights-activist-dies/2010/04/13/|accessdate=January 15, 2018|work=Anchorage Daily News|date=April 12, 2010}}</ref> At trial, Ravin's defense argued that the state constitution guaranteed a [[right to privacy]], which extended to the use of cannabis in one's home.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dunham|first1=Michael|title=When the Smoke Clears|url=http://reason.com/archives/1983/03/01/when-the-smoke-clears/print|accessdate=January 15, 2018|work=Reason|date=March 1, 1983}}</ref> In May 1975 the state Supreme Court agreed, legalizing the use, possession, and cultivation of cannabis in amounts for personal use.<ref name="Dufton" />
In the following years, decriminalization laws passed in [[Minnesota]] (1976), [[Mississippi]] (1977), [[New York (state)|New York]] (1977), [[North Carolina]] (1977), and [[Nebraska]] (1978).<ref name="Dufton" /> NORML was actively involved in helping to pass these laws, lobbying in support of legislation and paying for decriminalization proponents (including members of the Shafer Commission) to travel to various states to testify.<ref name="Dufton" />
During the 1970s various cities also passed decriminalization laws, such as [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]] in 1972 and [[Madison, Wisconsin]] in 1977.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Brush|first1=Mark|title=Sorting out the confusion over local marijuana laws, Ann Arbor's experience|url=http://michiganradio.org/post/sorting-out-confusion-over-local-marijuana-laws-ann-arbors-experience|accessdate=February 24, 2018|work=Michigan Radio|date=May 3, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cullen|first1=Sandy|title=30 Years Later Madison Voters Passed A Law In April 1977 That Permits Possession Of Small Amounts Of Marijuana In Private Places|url=http://host.madison.com/news/years-later-madison-voters-passed-a-law-in-april-that/article_fbb60aa4-99f6-59f6-870a-2021eeffd16c.html|accessdate=February 7, 2018|work=madison.com|date=April 10, 2007}}</ref> Additionally, [[San Francisco]] residents approved Proposition W in 1978, a non-binding measure directing city law enforcement to "cease the arrest and prosecution of individuals involved in the cultivation, transfer, or possession of marijuana".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Roberts|first1=Chris|title=SF's Dianne Feinstein: 'Worst Senator on Marijuana Reform'|url=http://www.sfweekly.com/news/sfs-dianne-feinstein-worst-senator-on-marijuana-reform/|accessdate=February 24, 2018|work=SF Weekly|date=July 1, 2015}}</ref> Mayor [[George Moscone]] was assassinated a few weeks later, however,<ref name="Lee" /> and the initiative was subsequently disregarded.<ref name="Heddleston" />
===Carter administration and resignation of Peter Bourne (1976 to 1978)=== As decriminalization efforts continued to progress during the 1970s, many supporters of reform – including Stroup himself – believed federal decriminalization was just around the corner.<ref name="Dufton" /> This optimism was particularly buoyed by the 1976 election of [[Presidency of Jimmy Carter|Jimmy Carter]], who spoke out in favor of decriminalization during his presidential campaign (earning him the support of both Stroup and NORML).<ref name="Dufton" /> Carter was urged to speak in support of decriminalization by [[Peter Bourne]], an Atlanta physician who grew close to Carter during his time as Georgia governor.<ref name="Dufton" /> Upon being elected president, Carter gave Bourne an office in the [[West Wing]] and the official title "Special Assistant to the President for Drug Abuse".<ref name="Dufton" /> From this position, Bourne continued to advocate for cannabis decriminalization, while also developing a close relationship with Stroup and NORML.<ref name="Dufton" /> In August 1977, the White House issued its first official position paper on drugs, which Stroup helped draft.<ref name="Dufton" /> Included in the paper was a call for up to one ounce of cannabis to be decriminalized at the federal level.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Walsh|first1=Edward|title=Carter Endorses Decriminalization Of Marijuana|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1977/08/03/carter-endorses-decriminalization-of-marijuana/7e4b0e9a-90c9-4bdb-a49b-57290236a671/|accessdate=January 24, 2018|work=The Washington Post|date=August 3, 1977}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Drug Abuse Message to the Congress|url=https://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/documents/drug-abuse-message-the-congress|accessdate=March 9, 2018|work=The American Presidency Project|date=August 2, 1977}}</ref>
By the fall of 1977, the relationship between Bourne and Stroup had begun to sour.<ref name="Dufton" /> The Carter administration was providing helicopters to the government of [[Mexico]], which were being used to eradicate cannabis crops by spraying the herbicide [[paraquat]].<ref name="Dufton" /> Stroup argued that these crops could find their way into the U.S. and harm American consumers of the drug. Simultaneously, Stroup was growing frustrated that the administration was not doing more to support the decriminalization policies that it had previously championed.<ref name="Dufton" /> By March 1978 Stroup's anger had reached a boiling point, as Bourne and the administration continued to support paraquat spraying in the face of growing public opposition to the practice (and emerging evidence that it posed a serious health risk).<ref name="Anderson" /> Stroup decided to take matters into his own hands, contacting reporter [[Gary Cohn (journalist)|Gary Cohn]] and informing him that Bourne had used [[cocaine]] at the annual Christmas party hosted by NORML a few months earlier.<ref name="Anderson" /> Although this information was not immediately published, in July 1978, when Bourne was in the midst of a scandal over writing an illegal prescription, the cocaine revelation came to light.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shaffer|first1=Ronald|title=Cocaine - Sniffing Incident|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1978/07/21/cocaine-sniffing-incident/9e5b6175-25a7-4169-8a8f-e12484aaa961/|accessdate=January 16, 2018|work=The Washington Post|date=July 21, 1978}}</ref> Faced with two simultaneous scandals of illegal prescription-writing and drug use, Bourne resigned from his position.<ref name="Anderson" />
The resignation of Peter Bourne was considered a significant blow for decriminalization proponents in a number of ways. First, there were no advisers pushing Carter to support decriminalization anymore, as Bourne's successor Lee Dogoloff was not particularly sympathetic to the cause.<ref name="Dufton" /> Also, the embarrassment of the Bourne scandal, along with allegations of drug use that had been made against other members of the administration, made decriminalization a much more politically sensitive topic that Carter thus sought to avoid.<ref name="Dufton" /> It was not just the Carter administration that had been damaged from the incident, however. Stroup's role in the scandal proved to be a major embarrassment for NORML, and by December 1978 led to his resignation, due to the anger and distrust that his actions had caused.<ref name="Anderson" /> The departure of Stroup also caused NORML to lose the support of some of its top donors, including its largest benefactor the [[Playboy Foundation]].<ref name="Heddleston" />
===Parent revolution, Reagan years, and recriminalization (late 1970s through 80s)=== By the end of 1970s, efforts to decriminalize cannabis had stalled at both the state and federal level. Although the fallout of the Bourne scandal played a significant role, there was another factor at play in bringing about this shift. A movement of anti-drug parent activists was rising up nationwide, galvanized by a spike in adolescent drug use and the wide availability of [[Drug paraphernalia|paraphernalia]] products for sale (some of which resembled children's toys).<ref name="Dufton" /> The movement sprang out of [[Atlanta]] in 1976, as a number of [[support group]]s were formed for parents concerned about teen drug use.<ref name="Dufton" /> The groups soon spread across the country, and subsequently turned attention to legislative affairs such as halting decriminalization efforts and passing anti-paraphernalia laws.<ref name="Dufton" /> The movement continued to grow as [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|President Reagan]] took office in 1981, with first lady [[Nancy Reagan]] particularly involving herself in the cause.<ref name="Dufton" /> Efforts to decriminalize cannabis had quickly been stamped out for the foreseeable future.
[[File:Smoke a joint, lose your license states.svg|thumb|right|265 px|alt=Map of jurisdictions that impose mandatory driver's license suspensions for possession of cannabis| '''Mandatory driver's license suspensions for possession of cannabis''' ---- {{legend|#E44317|Jurisdictions with mandatory suspensions}} {{legend|#C1C1C1|Jurisdictions that have opted out}} ]]
During the Reagan years, the federal war on drugs was significantly ramped up, and a number of states acted to increase penalties for drug crimes.<ref name="Dufton" /><ref name="Lee" /> Meanwhile, NORML struggled to regain the influence that it once held, as it dealt with significant decreases in funding and membership, and underwent frequent changes to organizational leadership.<ref name="Dufton" /> In 1985, part of NORML was split off to found the Drug Policy Foundation, which was then merged with the [[Lindesmith Center]] to become the [[Drug Policy Alliance]] in 2000.<ref name="Heddleston" /> Members of NORML further split off in 1995 to found the [[Marijuana Policy Project]].
In 1990, Alaska voters approved a ballot initiative to recriminalize cannabis, overriding the court decision that legalized cannabis 15 years earlier.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alaska Voters Approve Measure To Recriminalize Marijuana|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1990/Alaska-Voters-Approve-Measure-to-Recriminalize-Marijuana/id-4db1bf97a3d7c3a94c1d1e304f149c06|accessdate=January 19, 2017|work=Associated Press|date=November 7, 1990}}</ref> Also in 1990, the [[Solomon–Lautenberg amendment]] was passed at the federal level, leading many states to further criminalize cannabis by enacting "Smoke a joint, lose your license" laws.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ingram|first1=Carl|title='Smoke a Joint, Lose License' Law in Effect|url=http://articles.latimes.com/print/1994-12-01/news/mn-3616_1_drug-conviction|accessdate=January 19, 2018|work=Los Angeles Times|date=December 1, 1994}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=States Are Pressed to Suspend Driver Licenses of Drug Users|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/16/us/states-are-pressed-to-suspend-driver-licenses-of-drug-users.html|accessdate=January 28, 2018|work=The New York Times|agency=Associated Press|date=November 16, 1990}}</ref> These laws imposed mandatory driver's license suspensions for anyone committing a drug offense, even if no motor vehicle was involved.<ref>{{cite web|title=Reefer sanity: States abandon driver's license suspensions for drug offenses|url=http://clemencyreport.org/drivers-license-suspensions-drug-offenses-state-state-list/|website=The Clemency Report|accessdate=January 19, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180119234957/http://clemencyreport.org/drivers-license-suspensions-drug-offenses-state-state-list/|archive-date=January 19, 2018|dead-url=unfit}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Beitsch|first1=Rebecca|title=States Reconsider Driver's License Suspensions for People With Drug Convictions|url=http://www.pewtrusts.org/en/research-and-analysis/blogs/stateline/2017/01/31/states-reconsider-drivers-license-suspensions-for-people-with-drug-convictions|accessdate=January 19, 2018|work=Stateline|publisher=The Pew Charitable Trusts|date=January 31, 2017}}</ref> Many states have since acted to repeal such laws, but as of 2018 seven complying states still remained.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Aiken|first1=Joshua|title=Reinstating Common Sense: How driver's license suspensions for drug offenses unrelated to driving are falling out of favor|url=https://www.prisonpolicy.org/driving/national.html|accessdate=January 19, 2018|work=Prison Policy Initiative|date=December 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. Representative Beto O'Rourke Leads Bipartisan Bill that Repeals Federal Transportation Law Requiring States to Suspend Driver's Licenses for Drug Offenses|url=http://www.drugpolicy.org/news/2017/04/us-representative-beto-orourke-leads-bipartisan-bill-repeals-federal-transportation-law|accessdate=January 19, 2018|work=Drug Policy Alliance|date=April 5, 2017}}</ref>
===Second wave of decriminalization begins (2001)=== After Nebraska decriminalized cannabis in 1978, no other state would follow for over two decades, until [[Nevada]] decriminalized in 2001.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nevada Defelonizes Pot Possession -- State Eliminates Jail, Criminal Record for Minor Offenders; Legalizes Medical Marijuana for Seriously Ill|url=http://norml.org/news/2001/06/07/nevada-defelonizes-pot-possessionstate-eliminates-jail-criminal-record-for-minor-offenders-legalizes-medical-marijuana-for-seriously-ill|accessdate=February 9, 2018|work=NORML|date=June 7, 2001}}</ref> In subsequent years a number of major cities decriminalized cannabis or made enforcement of cannabis laws the lowest priority.<ref>{{cite cities to pass such laws were [[Seattle]] (2003),<ref>{{cite news|title=Seattle Voters Approve Initiative Making Marijuana Enforcement City's "Lowest
