news|last1=Starkey|first1=Jonathan|title=Marijuana decriminalization bill OK'd in Delaware|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/06/18/marijuana-decriminalization-bill-okd-delaware/28955055/|accessdate=January 19, 2018|work=USA Today|date=June 18, 2015}}</ref> [[Illinois]] (2016),<ref>{{cite news|last1=Monique|first1=Garcia|title=Rauner reduces punishment for minor pot possession from jail to citation|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-illinois-marijuana-decriminalzation-0730-20160729-story.html|accessdate=January 19, 2018|work=Chicago Tribune|date=July 29, 2016}}</ref> and [[New Hampshire]] (2017).<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Reid|title=NH governor signs marijuana decriminalization bill|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/342692-nh-governor-signs-marijuana-decriminalization-bill|accessdate=January 19, 2018|work=The Hill|date=July 19, 2017}}</ref> As of 2018 thirteen states had decriminalization policies in effect, and an additional eight states have decriminalized that later legalized.
===State recreational legalization begins (2012)=== Prior to 2012, [[Initiatives and referendums in the United States|ballot initiatives]] seeking to legalize cannabis were attempted in a number of states, but none succeeded. Among these attempts were California in 1972 (33% support), Oregon in 1986 (26%), Alaska in 2000 (41%), Nevada in 2002 (39%), Arizona in 2002 (43%), Alaska in 2004 (44%), Colorado in 2006 (46%), Nevada in 2006 (46%), and California in 2010 (47%).<ref name="ballotpedia">{{cite web|title=History of marijuana on the ballot|url=https://ballotpedia.org/History_of_marijuana_on_the_ballot|website=Ballotpedia|accessdate=January 21, 2018}}</ref>
In 2012, success was finally achieved for legalization advocates in the states of [[Washington (state)|Washington]] and [[Colorado]], when voters approved [[Initiative 502]] and [[Amendment 64]].<ref name="ballotpedia" /> In subsequent years, cannabis was legalized by ballot measure in [[Oregon]] (2014), [[Alaska]] (2014), the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] (2014), [[California]] (2016), [[Nevada]] (2016), [[Maine]] (2016), [[Massachusetts]] (2016), and [[Michigan]] (2018), and by an act of legislature in [[Vermont]] (2018) and the [[Northern Mariana Islands]] (2018). In all of these jurisdictions, commercial distribution of cannabis has been legalized except for Vermont and the District of Columbia.<ref name="NAMSDL">{{citation|title=Marijuana: Comparison of State Laws Legalizing Personal, Non-Medical Use|url=http://www.namsdl.org/library/33FD7B09-D862-91A9-48FFEFD87F5D4611/|work=National Alliance for Model State Drug Laws|date=December 23, 2016}}</ref> Personal cultivation of cannabis is allowed in all jurisdictions, except for Washington state. Public consumption and use by individuals under 21 are prohibited in all.<ref name="NAMSDL" />
====Federal response==== After the first states legalized in 2012, uncertainty remained over how the federal government would respond. Seeking to clarify, the Justice Department issued the [[Cole Memorandum]] in August 2013, which specified eight conditions under which enforcement of federal law would be prioritized (such as distribution of cannabis to minors or diversion of cannabis across state borders).<ref name="cole memo">{{cite news|last1=Rough|first1=Lisa|title=The Cole Memo: What Is It and What Does It Mean?|url=https://www.leafly.com/news/cannabis-101/what-is-the-cole-memo|accessdate=January 21, 2018|work=Leafly|date=September 14, 2017}}</ref> Aside from these situations, the memo generally allowed for the commercial distribution of cannabis in states where such activity has been legalized. The Cole memo was only a non-binding set of guidelines for [[United States Attorney|federal prosecutors]], however, and therefore did not carry the force of law.
Although the Cole memo was largely adhered to by federal prosecutors, members of Congress sought the assurances that a legally binding act of legislation could provide. The McClintock–Polis amendment was hence introduced in the U.S. House (as an attachment to the [[Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2016|CJS Appropriations Bill for fiscal year 2016]]) to prohibit the Justice Department from spending funds to interfere with the implementation of state cannabis laws (regarding both recreational and medical use).<ref>{{cite news |last1=Baca |first1=Ricardo |title=House passes bill to prevent DOJ from interfering in states’ medical pot laws |url=https://www.thecannabist.co/2015/06/03/house-medical-pot-marijuana/35704/ |accessdate=October 27, 2018 |work=The Cannabist |date=June 3, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=House Members Reauthorize Measure Protecting State Sanctioned Medical Marijuana Programs |url=http://norml.org/news/2015/06/04/house-members-reauthorize-measure-protecting-state-sanctioned-medical-marijuana-programs |accessdate=October 27, 2018 |work=NORML |date=June 4, 2015}}</ref> The McClintock–Polis amendment was narrowly defeated on June 3, 2015, by a vote of 206 to 222.<ref>{{cite web |title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 285 |url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2015/roll285.xml |website=house.gov |accessdate=October 26, 2018}}</ref>
The Cole memo remained in effect until January 2018, when it was rescinded by Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]].<ref name="rescission">{{cite news|last1=Gerstein|last2=Lima|first2=Cristiano|first1=Josh|title=Sessions announces end to policy that allowed legal pot to flourish|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/01/04/jeff-sessions-marijuana-policy-us-attorney-enforcement-324020|accessdate=January 21, 2018|work=Politico|date=January 4, 2018}}</ref> The intended impact of the rescission was not immediately made clear, however, in regards to what kind of crackdown (if any) on the states would be forthcoming.<ref name="rescission" /> In response to the memo's rescission, the [[STATES Act]] was introduced in Congress (upon consultation with [[Presidency of Donald Trump|President Trump]])<ref>{{cite news |last1=Angell |first1=Tom |title=Trump To Support Major Marijuana Legislation |url=https://www.marijuanamoment.net/trump-to-support-major-marijuana-legislation/ |accessdate=October 27, 2018 |work=Marijuana Moment |date=April 13, 2018}}</ref> to enshrine into law protections that the Cole memo previously provided.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Angell |first1=Tom |title=Senators File Marijuana Bill Following Trump Pledge To Respect State Legalization |url=https://www.marijuanamoment.net/watch-bipartisan-senators-discuss-marijuana-legislation/ |accessdate=October 27, 2018 |work=Marijuana Moment |date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> President Trump confirmed to reporters his intent to sign the STATES Act should it be approved by Congress.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ferner |first1=Matt |title=Trump Supports Relaxing Federal Pot Laws, In Blow To Jeff Sessions |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-marijuana-legalization_us_5b1abffbe4b0bbb7a0dc7d8a |accessdate=October 27, 2018 |work=HuffPost |date=June 8, 2018}}</ref>
== Arguments in support of reform == {{More citations needed|date=January 2016}}
In 1972, President [[Richard Nixon]] commissioned the [[National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse]] to produce an in-depth report on cannabis. The report, "Marijuana: A Signal of Misunderstanding", found cannabis prohibition constitutionally suspect and stated regardless of whether the courts would overturn prohibition of cannabis possession, the executive and legislative branches have a duty to obey the Constitution.<ref name=nixonreport>{{cite web|title=Marihuana: A Signal of Misunderstanding|publisher=[[National Commission on Marihuana and Drug Abuse]]|date=March 1972|url=http://www.druglibrary.org/schaffer/Library/studies/nc/ncmenu.htm|accessdate=2007-04-20}}</ref> "It's a matter of individual freedom of choice", said ACLU President [[Nadine Strossen]] in an interview. "Does that mean they should do it? Not necessarily, not any more than somebody should smoke or drink or eat [[McDonald's]] hamburgers."<ref>Shankbone, David. "[[n:ACLU President Strossen on religion, drugs, guns and impeaching George Bush#Gun rights|Interview with Nadine Strossen]]" ''[[Wikinews]]'' (2007-10-30). Retrieved 2007-11-14.</ref>
=== Potential medical benefits of marijuana === Marijuana (cannabis) is an herb drug, which contains a very active component delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC).<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/921580861/|title = Blurred Boundaries: The Therapeutics and Politics of Medical Marijuana|last = Bostwick|first = J. Michael|date = Feb 2012|journal = Mayo Clinic Proceedings|doi = 10.1016/j.mayocp.2011.10.003|pmid = 22305029|access-date= 2015-11-06 |volume=87 |issue = 2|pages=172–186|pmc=3538401}}</ref> For thousands of years, it was used for medical purposes in many different parts of the world. Recent studies also agreed that THC had great potential benefits for medical purposes. A number of patients who have HIV, multiple sclerosis (MS), neuropathic chronic pain, and cancer were under medical marijuana treatment. The treatments could either be smoke on cannabis or oral preparations, which were synthetic THC and synthetic equivalent.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/1691424098/|title = Medical Uses of Marijuana (Cannabis Sativa): Fact or Fallacy?|last = Maule|first = W.J.|date = 4 March 2015|journal = British Journal of Biomedical Science|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 2015-10-11}}</ref>
According to Medical Uses of Marijuana (Cannabis sativa), patients with HIV reported that the drug reduced mixed neuropathic pain more significantly in comparison to other placebo drugs. They addressed that there was a minimum of 30% pain reduction when they were under smoked medical marijuana treatment. Furthermore, under the same type of treatment, most of the patients with multiple sclerosis showed dramatic improvements on their symptoms.<ref name=":0" /> After the treatment, their handwriting was much clearer and head tremor pain was less than the samples taken before the treatment. In addition, many patients that associated with chronic pain, multiple sclerosis were also under marijuana oral preparation treatment. Patients treated with dronabinol, a synthetic THC, reported that there was a 50% pain reduction compared to 30% that was experienced when given the placebo. Furthermore, cancer treatment involving chemotherapy also agreed that dronabinol had significant benefits on delaying nausea and vomiting for patients.<ref name=":0" /> However, medical marijuana treatments are not for everyone and it may cause adverse side effects for others. Overall, the potential long-term side effects of medical marijuana are not yet fully classified. As a result, further studies must carry out to fully understand the benefits as well as adverse psychiatric and medical side effects of the drug.
=== Economic arguments === Many proponents of cannabis decriminalization have argued that decriminalizing cannabis would largely reduce costs of maintaining the criminal justice and law enforcement systems, while legalizing cannabis to allow the cultivation and sale would generate a substantial amount of income from taxing cannabis sales.
In 2005, more than 530 distinguished economists called for the legalization of cannabis in an open letter to [[George W. Bush|President Bush]], [[United States Congress|Congress]], [[Governors of the United States|Governors]], and state legislatures.<ref name=letter>{{cite web |url=http://www.prohibitioncosts.org/endorsers.html |title=Budgetary Implications of Marijuana Prohibition in the United States |accessdate=2008-02-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017021537/http://prohibitioncosts.org/endorsers.html |archivedate=2007-10-17 |df= }}</ref> The endorsers included conservative economist [[Milton Friedman]] and two other [[Nobel Prize]]-winners.<ref name=letter/>
The letter stated, among other things, "We, the undersigned, call your attention to the attached report [which]... shows that marijuana legalization — replacing prohibition with a system of taxation and regulation — would save $7.7 billion per year in state and federal expenditures on prohibition enforcement and produce tax revenues of at least $2.4 billion annually if marijuana were taxed like most consumer goods. If, however, marijuana were taxed similarly to alcohol or tobacco, it might generate as much as $6.2 billion annually...."
We therefore urge the country to commence an open and honest debate about marijuana prohibition. We believe such a debate will favor a regime in which marijuana is legal but taxed and regulated like other goods. At a minimum, this debate will force advocates of current policy to show that prohibition has benefits sufficient to justify the cost to taxpayers, foregone tax revenues, and numerous ancillary consequences that result from marijuana prohibition."
The report also projected the tax revenues from decriminalization, by state.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/pf/features/lists/taxes_marijuana/table.html|title=CNN Money: State Marijuana Tax Revenues|publisher=}}</ref>
Other arguments point out that the funds saved from cannabis decriminalization could be used to enforce laws for other, more serious and violent crimes.<ref name=msnbc1>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/15305579/from/RS.5/|date=2006-10-17|title=Nevadans to vote on legalizing marijuana|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|accessdate=2007-03-27}}</ref><ref name=nm>{{cite web|url=http://www.drugpolicy.org/library/gov_johnson2.cfm|title=Report and Recommendations: Governor's Drug Policy Advisory Group|publisher=[[Drug Policy Alliance]]|date=January 2001|accessdate=2007-03-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070606042550/http://www.drugpolicy.org/library/gov_johnson2.cfm|archivedate=2007-06-06|df=}}</ref>
In 1988, Michael Aldrich and Tod Mikuriya published "Savings in California Marijuana Law Enforcement Costs Attributable to the Moscone Act of 1976" in the ''[[Journal of Psychoactive Drugs]]''. The study estimated [[California]] saved almost one billion dollars in a twelve-year period between 1976 and 1988, as a result of the Moscone Act of 1976 that decriminalized cannabis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marijuanalibrary.org/JPD_Savings_1988.txt|title=Savings in California Marijuana Law Enforcement Costs Attributable to the Moscone Act of 1976 - A Summary |publisher= marijuanalibrary.org |accessdate= 2007-03-20}}</ref>
In 2003, the [[Office of National Drug Control Policy]] (ONDCP) published "Economic Costs of Drug Abuse", which stated without separately analyzing cannabis related costs, the United States was spending $12.1 billion on law enforcement and court costs, and $16.9 billion in corrections costs, totaling $29 billion.<ref name="norml">{{cite web|url= http://www.norml.org/pdf_files/NORML_Rethinking_Decriminalizing_Marijuana.pdf|author=James Austin|publisher= The JFA Institute (published on [[National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (United States)|NORML]])|title=Rethinking the Consequences of Decriminalizing Marijuana|date=2005-11-02|accessdate=2006-12-24}}</ref>
In 2004, Scott Bates of the Boreal Economic Analysis & Research center prepared a study for Alaskans for Rights & Revenues entitled "The Economic Implications of Marijuana Legalization in Alaska." The study estimated the [[Alaska]]n government was spending $25–30 million per year enforcing cannabis prohibition laws. The study found if the purchase of cannabis were to be taxed as a legal commodity, tax revenues would increase by about $10–20 million per year, making $35–50 million per year in funds available.<ref name=norml/><ref name="prohibcosts">{{cite web|url=http://www.prohibitioncosts.org/FinalBatesreport.pdf|title=The Economic Implications of Marijuana Legalization in Alaska|publisher=prohibitioncosts.org|accessdate=2007-03-21}}</ref>
In 2006, a study by [[Jon Gettman]] entitled "Marijuana Production in the United States" was published in the ''Bulletin of Cannabis Reform''. The report states cannabis is the top cash crop in 12 states, is one of the top three cash crops in 30 states, and is one of the top five cash crops in 39 states. Gettman estimated the value of U.S. cannabis production at $35.8 billion, which is more than the combined value of corn and wheat. Furthermore, the report states according to federal estimates, eradication efforts have failed to prevent the spread of cannabis production, as cannabis production has increased tenfold in the past 25 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drugscience.org/Archive/bcr2/MJCropReport_2006.pdf|title=Marijuana Production in the United States|website=drugscience.org|year=2006|accessdate=2007-03-20|author=Jon Gettman}}</ref>
In 2006, the [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]] released the 2006 World Drug Report, which stated the North American cannabis market is estimated to be worth anywhere from $10 billion to $60 billion annually.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://baltimorechronicle.com/2006/091506HICKMAN.shtml|title=UNODC Makes the Case for Ending Cannabis Prohibition—Inadvertently|first=John|last=Hickman|publisher=[[Baltimore Chronicle]]|accessdate=2007-06-20}}</ref> That same study also indicated that the mountainous regions in Appalachia, and the rural areas of the West Coast are ideal for growing cannabis. Allowing farmers there to grow cannabis openly would both provide jobs and reduce the need for expensive federal welfare payments to those areas, which are disproportionately dependent on welfare.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statemaster.com/graph/eco_wel_cas_tot_rec_percap-caseloads-total-recipients-per-capita|title=Welfare Caseloads Total recipients (per capita) (most recent) by state}}</ref>
In 2006, a study by the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] found [[California]] has saved $2.50 for every dollar invested into [[California Proposition 36 (2000)|Proposition 36]], which decriminalized cannabis and other drug possession charges by allowing out patient treatment programs instead of incarceration. In the first year the proposition was enacted (2001), California reportedly saved $173 million, which is likely a result of fewer drug offenders in prison. In the five years after the program was enacted, 8,700 fewer people are in prison for drug offenses.<ref>{{cite news |authors=Jason Ziedenberg and Rose Braz |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20060417/news_mz1e17zieden.html |title=Saving money and aiding drug users |work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |date=2006-04-17 |accessdate=2007-03-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070506150333/http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20060417/news_mz1e17zieden.html |archivedate=2007-05-06 |df= }}</ref>
Since cannabis is illegal in the United States, this policy has led to penalties for simple use and possession. Despite these penalties, users continue to find themselves in trouble with the law. The Connecticut Law Revision Commission made the following evaluation: "(1) the costs of arresting and prosecuting marijuana offenders were significantly lower in states that had done away with criminal penalties for possessing small amounts; (2) there was a greater increase in marijuana use in states that continue to treat possession as crime than in states that treated it as a civil offense; (3) easing the penalties for marijuana did not lead to a substantial increase in the use of either alcohol or hard drugs."<ref>Ruschmann, J.D. (2004). ''Legalizing Marijuana'', Paul Chelsea House Publishers.</ref>
=== Reduction of income earned by organized crime === The [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] has reported that cannabis sales and trafficking support violent criminal gangs.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.usdoj.gov/ndic/pubs11/12620/marijuana.htm |title=National Drug Threat Assessment 2006|publisher=[[National Drug Intelligence Center]]|date=February 2005|accessdate=2007-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/ndic/pubs8/8731/marijuana.htm|title=National Drug Threat Assessment 2004|publisher=[[National Drug Intelligence Center]]|date=April 2004|accessdate=2007-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/ndic/pubs/653/marijuan.htm|title=California Northern and Eastern Districts Drug Threat Assessment|publisher=[[National Drug Intelligence Center]]|date=January 2001|accessdate=2007-04-03}}</ref> Proponents of fully decriminalizing cannabis to allow the regulated cultivation and sale of cannabis, including [[Law Enforcement Against Prohibition]], argue that fully decriminalizing cannabis would largely decrease financial gains earned by gangs in black market cannabis sales and trafficking.<ref name=msnbc1 /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://leap.cc/Speakers/speakerbio.php?spkr=./Bios/becker.inc&name=Dean%20Becker|title=Dean Becker|publisher=[[Law Enforcement Against Prohibition]]|accessdate=2007-04-03}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2002/Nov-06-Wed-2002/news/20007394.html|author=Ed Vogel|title=Legalization Initiative: Marijuana measure opposed|work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|date=2006-04-11|accessdate=2007-04-19}}</ref>
===Displacement of alcohol consumption=== A study in the ''[[Journal of Policy Analysis and Management]]'' by Mark Anderson and Daniel Reese indicated that increased marijuana use in California is a substitute for alcohol. This research showed that participants frequently choose marijuana over other substances. They reported that over 41 percent of the people said that they prefer to use marijuana instead of alcohol. Some of the main reasons for this substitute were 'less withdrawal', 'fewer side-effects' and 'better symptom management'.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Paul Armentano |url=http://www.alternet.org/drugs/marijuana-exit-drug-study-suggests-some-are-taking-it-substitute-prescription-drugs-and |title=Is Marijuana an 'Exit Drug'? Study Suggests Some Are Taking It as a Substitute for Prescription Drugs and Alcohol |journal=Alternet |date=2012-12-26 |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/27/us/few-problems-with-cannabis-for-california.html?_r=0 | title=Few Problems With Cannabis for California | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=October 26, 2013 | accessdate=2014-05-05 |author1=Naggourney, Adam |author2=Lyman, Rick }}</ref>
[[Secretary of State of California|California Secretary of State's office]] said that on September 7, 2010 the beer lobby donated $10,000 to Public Safety First, a group which opposed the passage of Proposition 19 to legalize cannabis.<ref name=laweekly>{{cite web |author=J. Patrick Coolican |url=http://www.laweekly.com/informer/2010/09/21/beer-lobby-gives-10000-to-no-on-proposition-19-pot-legalization |title=Beer Lobby Gives $10,000 To 'No' On Proposition 19 Pot Legalization |publisher=LA Weekly |date=2013-10-03 |accessdate=2014-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503000347/http://www.laweekly.com/informer/2010/09/21/beer-lobby-gives-10000-to-no-on-proposition-19-pot-legalization |archivedate=2014-05-03 |df= }}</ref>
=== Reduction of subsequent abuse of other illicit drugs === The Marijuana Policy Project argues that:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mpp.org/assets/pdfs/download-materials/TandRARGUMENTS092008.pdf |title=Effective Arguments for Advocates of Taxing and Regulating Marijuana |accessdate=2008-10-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918173659/http://www.mpp.org/assets/pdfs/download-materials/TandRARGUMENTS092008.pdf |archivedate=2008-09-18 |df= }}</ref>
{{quote|Research shows that the actual "gateway" is the illegal drug market. The World Health Organization noted that any gateway effect associated with marijuana use may actually be due to marijuana prohibition because "exposure to other drugs when purchasing cannabis on the black-market increases the opportunity to use other illicit drugs." A study comparing experienced cannabis users in Amsterdam, where adults can purchase small amounts of cannabis from regulated businesses, with similarly experienced cannabis users in San Francisco, where non-medical possession and sale of cannabis remains completely illegal, bolstered this hypothesis: The San Francisco cannabis users were twice as likely to use crack cocaine as their Dutch counterparts, more than twice as likely to use amphetamines, and five times as likely to be current users of opiates.}}
=== Health effects of cannabis === [[File:Rational scale to assess the harm of drugs (mean physical harm and mean dependence).svg|thumb|Comparison of the perceived harm for various psychoactive drugs from a poll among medical psychiatrists specialized in addiction treatment (David Nutt et al. 2007).<ref name="Nutt">{{Cite journal | journal = The Lancet | first4 = C. | last4 = Blakemore | authorlink4 = Colin Blakemore| authorlink1 = David Nutt | volume = 369 | issue = 9566 | pmid=17382831 | pages = 1047–1053 | first3 = W. | last3 = Saulsbury | year = 2007 | title = Development of a rational scale to assess the harm of drugs of potential misuse | last1 = Nutt | first1 = D. | first2 = L. A. | last2 = King | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(07)60464-4}}</ref>]] {{See also|Effects of cannabis}}
Cannabis has been subject to many studies over the past century. Studies acknowledge that cannabis can in rare cases cause adverse reactions, but is generally safer than any commonly consumed drug such as [[alcohol]], [[tobacco]] and [[pharmaceuticals]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.saferchoice.org/content/view/24/53/ |title=Safer - Marijuana vs. Alcohol |publisher=Saferchoice.org |date=2006-05-25 |accessdate=2013-07-06|isbn=9781603585101 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/01/120110163444.htm |title=Marijuana smoke not as damaging to lungs as cigarette smoke, study suggests |journal=JAMA |volume=307 |issue=2 |pages=173–81 |doi=10.1001/jama.2011.1961 |pmid=22235088 |pmc=3840897 |date=2012-01-11 |accessdate=2013-07-06|last1=Pletcher |first1=Mark J. |last2=Vittinghoff |first2=Eric |last3=Kalhan |first3=Ravi |last4=Richman |first4=Joshua |last5=Safford |first5=Monika |last6=Sidney |first6=Stephen |last7=Lin |first7=Feng |last8=Kertesz |first8=Stefan }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vimm.ca/medical/marijuana-versus-addictive-pharmaceuticals/ |title=Marijuana versus Addictive Pharmaceuticals |publisher=Vimm.ca |date= |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref> In fact, in an article published in 'The Lancet' journal about the adverse health effects of non-medical cannabis use, Professors Hall and Degenhardt clearly stated that "the public health burden of cannabis use is probably modest compared with that of alcohol, tobacco, and other illicit drugs."<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hall | first1 = W. | last2 = Degenhardt | first2 = L. | year = 2009 | title = Adverse Health Effects Of Non-medical Cannabis Use | url = http://www.ramonausd.net/cms/lib07/CA01000789/Centricity/Domain/147/Adverse%20health%20effects%20of%20non-medical%20cannabis%20use.pdf | format = PDF | journal = The Lancet | volume = 374 | issue = 9698 | pages = 1383–1391 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(09)61037-0 | pmid = 19837255 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Psychopharmacologist [[David Nutt]] argues, though he is against full declassification, that the harm caused by cannabis is far less than that caused by alcohol or tobacco, which, if they were invented today "would be illegal.",{{citation needed|date=October 2011}}.
=== Reduction in prison overcrowding and strain on the criminal justice system === Supporters of decriminalization argue that if cannabis were to be legalized it would reduce the amount of non violent offenders in prison making room for the incarceration of more violent offenders as well as easing the current strain that the large amount of cannabis possession cases have on the criminal justice system. They also propose that it would also save taxpayers the cost of incarceration for these non violent offenders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.umsl.edu/~keelr/180/2003_pot_arrests.htm |title=Marijuana Arrests at All-Time High, Far Exceed Violent Crime Arrests |publisher=Umsl.edu |date=2004-10-29 |accessdate=2010-09-15}}</ref>
In the 1970s, there were just under 200,000 criminals serving time in state and federal prisons and an upwards of 750,000 in local jails for marijuana related crimes. Today there are over 1.5 million Americans serving time in an institution. If marijuana was decriminalized, these numbers were further be reduced again to below 700,000 inmates and save the taxpayers billions of dollars per year.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://norml.org/news/2007/11/21/decriminalizing-pot-will-reduce-prison-population-have-no-adverse-impact-on-public-safety-study-says|title = Unlocking America: Why and How to Reduce America's Prison Population|date = 21 November 2007|accessdate = 2014-10-24|website = Decriminalizing Pot Will Reduce Prison Population, Have No Adverse Impact On Public Safety, Study Says|publisher = NORML}}</ref>
The United States spends an estimated $68 billion per year on prisoners with a third of that number have been incarcerated for non-violent drug crimes including a sixth of those numbers as marijuana drug related offenses. A reduction in the prison population due to decriminalizing marijuana could save an average of $11.3 billion per year on courts, police, prison guards and other related expenses.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://sundial.csun.edu/2009/11/legalizing-marijuana-can-reduce-crime-increase-revenue-for-state/|title = Daily Sundial|date = 9 November 2009|accessdate = 2014-10-24|website = Legalizing marijuana can reduce crime, increase revenue for state|publisher = The Sundial California State University Northridge|last = Wolff|first = Madeline}}</ref>
=== Success of progressive drug policies adopted in other countries === Studies on decriminalization of marijuana in [[Drug policy of Portugal|Portugal]] have indicated it to be a "huge success".<ref name="healthland.time.com">{{cite news|last=Szalavitz |first=Maia |url=http://healthland.time.com/2010/11/23/portugals-drug-experience-new-study-confirms-decriminalization-was-a-success/ |title=Portugal's Drug Experience: New Study Confirms Decriminalization Was a Success |publisher=Healthland.time.com |date=2010-11-23 |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref> Drug use rates in Portugal were found to be dramatically lower than the United States with decriminalization enacted.<ref name="healthland.time.com"/>
Teenage use of marijuana in the Netherlands where it is [[Drug policy of the Netherlands|sold legally and openly]] is lower than in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|last=Downs |first=David |url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/LegalizationNation/archives/2011/09/22/going-dutch-teen-marijuana-use-in-the-us-vs-netherlands-the-full-interview-with-cal-professor-robert-maccoun |title=Going Dutch: Teen Marijuana Use in the US vs. Netherlands — the Full Interview with Cal Professor Robert MacCoun | Legalization Nation |publisher=East Bay Express |date=2011-09-22 |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drugwarfacts.org/cms/netherlands_v_us |title=The Netherlands Compared With The United States |publisher=Drug War Facts |date= |accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref>
Uruguay became the first country in the world to completely legalize marijuana.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Maier|first1=Shana L.|last2=Mannes|first2=Suzanne|last3=Koppenhofer|first3=Emily L.|title=The Implications of Marijuana Decriminalization and Legalization on Crime in the United States|journal=Contemporary Drug Problems|date=8 May 2017|volume=44|issue=2|pages=125–146|doi=10.1177/0091450917708790}}</ref>
=== Individual freedom === Some people are in favor of decriminalization and legalization of marijuana simply for the moral stance that individuals' freedom for [[property rights]] should be respected. This view is generally held in [[libertarianism|libertarian]] politics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lp.org/blogs/nigel-lyons/regulate-marijuana-like-wine|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120115652/http://www.lp.org/blogs/nigel-lyons/regulate-marijuana-like-wine|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-01-20|title=Regulate Marijuana like Wine|work=Libertarian Party}}</ref> This view is that regardless of any health effects of someone's lifestyle choice, if they are not directly harming anyone else or their property then they should be free to do what they want. Many people who support drug freedom policies may personally be strongly against drug use personally but still wants to protect the freedom of others to do so.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thenation.com/blog/171252/congressmen-pressure-obama-new-marijuana-laws|title=Barney Frank, Ron Paul Pressure Obama on New Marijuana Laws|journal=The Nation|date=14 November 2012}}</ref>
===Investors===
In order to effectively campaign to legalize recreational cannabis use millions of dollars have been spent to lobby for this reform. [[George Soros]] is a billionaire hedge fund manager that has spent over $25 million on marijuana reform efforts.<ref name=ForbesSoros>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/chloesorvino/2014/10/02/an-inside-look-at-the-biggest-drug-reformer-in-the-country-george-soros/|title=An Inside Look At The Biggest Drug Reformer In The Country: George Soros|publisher=Forbes|date=2014-10-02|author=Chloe Sorvino|accessdate=2015-02-25}}</ref> In 2010 Soros wrote an op-ed in the ''[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]]'' citing the fact that African Americans are no more likely than other Americans to use marijuana but are far more likely to be arrested for possession.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/oct/26/soros-marijuana-donation |title=George Soros gives $1m to California's pro-cannabis campaign |newspaper=The Guardian |author=Suzanne Goldenberg |date=2010-10-26 |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref>
Soros efforts to reform marijuana laws were predated by fellow billionaire, the late Peter Lewis. Lewis was the former chairman of Progressive Insurance and died November 23, 2013.<ref name=forbes>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/luisakroll/2013/11/24/billionaire-peter-lewis-who-fought-to-legalize-marjuana-has-died/ |title=Billionaire Peter Lewis, Advocate Of Marijuana Legalization, Dies At 80 |publisher=Forbes |author=Luisa Kroll |date=2013-11-24 |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref> Lewis is considered to be the most high-profile billionaire backer of drug reform and the [[National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws]] (NORML) estimated that Lewis had spent well over $40 million funding the cause since the 1980s.<ref name=forbes/> During the November 2012 election, he spent almost $3 million helping secure the passage of marijuana legalization bills in both Washington state and Massachusetts.<ref name=forbes/> The list of capitalists who have joined Soros and Lewis in the cause of Marijuana reform include John Sperling, who is the founder of the University of Phoenix and George Zimmer who is the founder and former CEO of Men's Wearhouse. Sperling donated $70,000 to support marijuana law reform in Oregon,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://truth-out.org/news/item/9260-marijuana-advocates-spend-big-and-defeat-drug-war-proponent-in-oregon |title=Marijuana Advocates Spend Big and Defeat Drug War Proponent in Oregon |publisher=Truthout |date=2012-05-20 |accessdate=2014-05-04 |author=Zaid Jilani}}</ref> and Zimmer contributed $20,000 to advocate for marijuana decriminalization in California.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/36179727 |title=The Marijuana Lobby: All Grown Up |author=Rob Reuteman |publisher=CNBC |date=2010-04-20 |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref>
These capitalists have helped pave the way for a new type of business with special interests in the cannabis industry. The ArcView Group was founded in 2010 by Silicon Valley entrepreneurs and marijuana advocates Troy Dayton and Steve DeAngelo.<ref name=wsj>{{cite press release|url=https://www.wsj.com/article/PR-CO-20130502-904140.html |title=ArcView Angel Investors Commit Over $1 Million to Marijuana Industry Start-ups at Seattle Event |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2013-05-02 |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref> Their company teams up angel investors with companies that produce cannabis products and it's been one of the major sources of startup revenue for cannabis-related companies.<ref name=wsj/> This company has contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to educational reform groups like the Students for [[Students for Sensible Drug Policy|Sensible Drug Policy]] and a pro-legalization PAC run by the Marijuana Policy Project.<ref name=wsj/>
===The ACLU and NAACP=== The ACLU takes a firm position that decriminalizing cannabis will keep tens of thousands of people from entering into the criminal justice system<ref name="marijuana-law-reform">{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/criminal-law-reform/marijuana-law-reform |title=Marijuana Law Reform |publisher=American Civil Liberties Union |date= |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref> as police efforts result in both unnecessary arrests and the enforcement of marijuana laws wastes billions of tax payers' dollars.<ref name=billions>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/billions-dollars-wasted-racially-biased-arrests |title=Billions of Dollars Wasted on Racially Biased Arrests |publisher=American Civil Liberties Union |date= |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref> They affirm that removing criminal penalties for marijuana offenses will therefore reduce the U.S. prison population and more effectively protect the public and promote public health.<ref name="marijuana-law-reform"/> One of the reasons that the ACLU has been such a strong supporter of drug decriminalization is that according to their research drug related arrests have largely driven America's incarceration rate to unacceptable levels. Drug offenders comprise over 500,000 of the more than 2 million people in America's prisons and jails, and drug offenses combined with failed drug tests account for a significant number of those returning to prison for parole and probation violations.<ref name="marijuana-law-reform"/> Between 2001 and 2010, there were over 7 million pot arrests in the U.S. and of these arrests 88% were for simply having marijuana.<ref name="aclu-marijuana-arrests-numbers">{{cite web|title=Marijuana Arrests By The Numbers|url=https://www.aclu.org/gallery/marijuana-arrests-numbers|website=American Civil Liberties Union|accessdate=2018-01-29}}</ref> These marijuana related arrests now account for over half of all drug related arrests in the United States.<ref name="marijuana-law-reform"/> These arrests tend to be racially imbalanced as a black person is 3.73 times more likely to be arrested than a white person for marijuana related charges,<ref name="marijuana-law-reform"/> despite research that suggests fairly equal usage rates between the two races.<ref name="aclu-marijuana-arrests-numbers"/> The ACLU is further troubled by the amount of money that is spent annually to enforce marijuana laws as they claim that over 3 billion dollars are spent every year by states to enforce marijuana regulation,<ref name="aclu-marijuana-arrests-numbers"/> while the drug's availability has not declined.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/criminal-law-reform/war-marijuana-black-and-white-report |title=The War on Marijuana in Black and White: Report |publisher=American Civil Liberties Union |date=2013-06-03 |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref> The ACLU claims that over 50% of Americans support marijuana legalization<ref name="aclu-marijuana-arrests-numbers"/> and they are advocating for the legalization of Cannabis through the Criminal Law Reform Project.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/issues/criminal-law-reform |title=Criminal Law Reform |publisher=American Civil Liberties Union |date= |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref> They believe that the resources that are spent on enforcing marijuana law could be better invested in our communities through education and job training.<ref name=billions/>
The NAACP has taken a similar stance and has cited the same data used by the ACLU.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/rhode-island/statements/2014/mar/16/naacp/new-england-naacp-says-african-americans-us-are-ar/ |title=New England NAACP says African-Americans in U.S. are arrested on marijuana charges at more than three times the rate of whites |publisher=Politifact |date= |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref> The NAACP has been strong supporters of the [[Legal history of cannabis in the United States|Respect State Marijuana Laws Act]] – H.R. 1523 and has reached out to members of congress to get this act passed.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/09/marijuana-naacp_n_4246693.html |title=Bipartisan Marijuana Bill Appears To Have One More Big Supporter In Its Corner: The NAACP |publisher=The Huffington Post |date=2013-11-09 |accessdate=2014-05-04 |author=Chris Gentilviso}}</ref> This act is designed to decrease penalties for low-level marijuana possession and supports prohibiting federal enforcement of marijuana laws in states which have lesser penalties.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naacp.org/press/entry/naacp-passes-resolution-on-hr.-1523 |title=NAACP Passes Resolution on HR. 1523 |publisher=NAACP |date=2013-11-13 |accessdate=2014-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20140206014250/http%3A//www.naacp.org/press/entry/naacp%2Dpasses%2Dresolution%2Don%2Dhr.%2D1523 |archivedate=2014-02-06 |df= }}</ref>
=== Racial bias === There are claims of historical evidence showing that a significant reason for marijuana ban by US government was political and racist in nature, aimed to suppress Black and Mexican minorities. A quote from 1934 newspaper
<blockquote>Marihuana influences Negroes to look at white people in the eye, step on white men's shadows and look at a white woman twice.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Guither|first1=Pete|title=Why is Marijuana Illegal|url=http://www.drugwarrant.com/articles/why-is-marijuana-illegal/|website=drugwarrant.com}}</ref></blockquote>
Loo, Hoorens, Hof and Kahan also talked about this issue in their book 'Cannabis policy, implementation and outcomes'. According to them, statistics show that controlling cannabis use leads in many cases to selective law enforcement, which increases the chances of arresting people from certain ethnicities. For example, while Blacks and Hispanics constitute about 20% of cannabis users in the US, they accounted for 58% of cannabis offenders sentenced under federal law in 1994.<ref>Loo, M. v., Hoorens, S., Hof, C. v., & Kahan, J. P. (2003). Cannabis policy and social consequences. Cannabis policy, implementation and outcomes (50-63). Santa Monica, CA: Rand.</ref>
=== Occupational Health and Safety === Since cannabis is still recognized as an illegal substance under federal law, each state has their own rules and regulations with regards to cannabis cultivation. As this is still a relatively new industry, there are challenges in formulating safety regulations; much discrepancy exists between state regulations and federal regulations with respect to legal agricultural practices.<ref name="dilemma">{{Cite journal|date=2014-08-01|title=Cannabis, pesticides and conflicting laws: The dilemma for legalized States and implications for public health|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S027323001400097X|journal=Regulatory Toxicology and Pharmacology|language=en|volume=69|issue=3|pages=284–288|doi=10.1016/j.yrtph.2014.05.015|pmid=24859075|issn=0273-2300|last1=Stone|first1=Dave}}</ref> Since there are no federal regulations on pesticide use in cannabis cultivation, none are registered for use in the United States, and illegal pesticide use is common. Samples purchased by law enforcement in California, have for example detected pesticide residues present on cannabis product for sale to the public.<ref name="dilemma" /> Workers risk exposure to THC, pesticides, and fertilizers through respiratory, dermal, and ocular pathways. One grower was reported to have developed [[pruritus]] and contact [[Hives|uticaria]] from simply handling the plants, after being tolerant to moderate use before. Other allergic reactions, such as asthma, rhinitis, conjunctivitis, and cutaneous symptoms have been reported.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehstoday.com/safety/study-cannabis-workers-value-safety-lack-formal-training|title=Study: Cannabis Workers Value Safety but Lack Formal Training|date=2018-03-27|work=EHS Today|access-date=2018-10-30}}</ref> Workers are also at risk of overexposure to UV rays from lamps used, and overexposure to carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and nitrogen oxides from devices used to promote cannabis growth. Cuts, nicks, and scrapes are also a risk during the harvest of cannabis buds. A survey completed by the CDPHE has found that while workers valued safety, 46%<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://workersafety.3m.com/growing-worker-safety-concerns-medical-marijuana-industry/|title=Growing Worker Safety Concerns in the Medical Marijuana Industry|date=April 17, 2018|website=3M|access-date=October 30, 2018}}</ref> of them never received any training in safety procedures and protocols. Washington and [https://www.colorado.gov/pacific/cdphe/marijuana-occupational-safety-and-health Colorado] have published valuable state guides with state regulations and best practices.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.colorado.gov/pacific/cdphe/marijuana-occupational-safety-and-health|title=Marijuana occupational safety and health {{!}} Department of Public Health and Environment|website=www.colorado.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-10-30}}</ref>
=== Environmental Safety === '''Pesticide Use''': "The [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)]] regulates pesticide use on agricultural crops, but has not tested any pesticides for use on marijuana because it is still illegal at the federal level. Given what is known about the chemicals commonly used on marijuana plants, that means a potential public health hazard for the millions of people who smoke or consume marijuana, as well as those who work at the grow operations."<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2015/06/17/413429435/growing-concern-over-unregulated-pesticide-use-among-marijuana-growers|title=Concern Grows Over Unregulated Pesticide Use Among Marijuana Growers|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-10-30|language=en}}</ref>
According to a 2013 study published in the ''Journal of Toxicology'' that assessed quantities of pesticides marijuana smokers were exposed to, it was found that "recoveries of residues were as high as 69.5% depending on the device used and the component investigated, suggesting that the potential of pesticide and chemical residue exposures to cannabis users is substantial and may pose a significant toxicological threat in the absence of adequate regulatory frameworks".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sullivan|first=Nicholas|last2=Elzinga|first2=Sytze|last3=Raber|first3=Jeffrey C.|date=2013|title=Determination of Pesticide Residues in Cannabis Smoke|journal=Journal of Toxicology|language=en|volume=2013|pages=1–6|doi=10.1155/2013/378168|issn=1687-8191|pmc=3666265|pmid=23737769}}</ref> Marijuana also differs from other agricultural products in that it can not be rinsed with water as the product is traditionally dried or cured.
The following six pesticides are considered highly toxic but commonly used on marijuana crops:
# [[Myclobutanil]] (fungicide): Developmental and reproductive toxin; Not allowed in WA or CO, found on tested samples in CO and OR # [[Pyrethrin]] (insecticide): Carcinogen; Approved in CO and WA # [[Fenoxycarb]] (insecticide): Carciniogen, cholinesterase inhibitor; not allowed in WA # [[Thiophanate-methyl]] (fungicide): Carcinogen; Not allowed in WA or CO, found on tested samples in CO. # [[Avermectin|Avermectin-]] (insectide): Developmental and reproductive toxin: not allowed in CO or WA, but found on tested samples in CO # [[Bifenthrin]] (insectide): Developmental and reproductive toxin, possible carcinogen; Not allowed in CO or WA, but found on tested samples in CO and OR<ref name=":1" />
Myclobutanil is the active chemical compound in the pesticide Eagle 20EW, the use of which is prohibited in Colorado. However, Eagle 20EW is still a commonly used pesticide. The federal limit, set by the EPA, for the amount in myclobutanil residue on lettuce is 0.3 parts per million – yet the amount tested on marijuana in Denver has at times reached 23.83 parts per million.<ref name=":1" />
A complete list of pesticides allowed for use on cannabis in Colorado approved by the Colorado Department of Agriculture is available [https://www.colorado.gov/pacific/agplants/pesticide-use-cannabis-production-information here], and for Washington state as approved by the Washington State Department of Agriculture is available [https://agr.wa.gov/pestfert/pesticides/pesticideuseonmarijuana.aspx here].
'''Energy Use''': Indoor marijuana cultivation is highly energy intensive. It is estimated that the industry accounts for 1% of all the nation's electricity use, which is six times the amount the pharmaceutical industry consumes. In terms of emissions, it is estimated that fifteen million metric tons of carbon are produced by the industry annually. Legalization would require those in the industry to meet long standing statutes such as the Clean Air Act, as well as give the opportunity to states to enforce provisions on energy use through conditions of licensure. For example in the city of Boulder, Colorado, marijuana businesses are required to utilize renewable energy to offset 100% of their electricity consumption.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gina|first=Warren,|date=2014-09-24|title=Regulating Pot to Save the Polar Bear: Energy and Climate Impacts of the Marijuana Industry|url=https://ssrn.com/abstract=2501126|language=en}}</ref>
'''Ecosystem:''' A single mature marijuana plant can consume 23 liters of water a day, compared to 13 liters for a grape plant. Historically, many outdoor cultivators have used illegal river and lake diversions to irrigate crops. These diversions have led to dewatering of streams and rivers which is well documented in areas of Northern California. As with any other agricultural crop, increase in demand leads to increased clear cutting of forests which can increase erosion, habitat destruction, and river diversion. Legalization and subsequent regulation could mitigate such issues.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carah|first=Jennifer K.|last2=Howard|first2=Jeanette K.|last3=Thompson|first3=Sally E.|last4=Short Gianotti|first4=Anne G.|last5=Bauer|first5=Scott D.|last6=Carlson|first6=Stephanie M.|last7=Dralle|first7=David N.|last8=Gabriel|first8=Mourad W.|last9=Hulette|first9=Lisa L.|date=2015-06-19|title=High Time for Conservation: Adding the Environment to the Debate on Marijuana Liberalization|journal=BioScience|language=en|volume=65|issue=8|pages=822–829|doi=10.1093/biosci/biv083|issn=1525-3244|pmc=4776720|pmid=26955083}}</ref>
== Arguments in opposition to reform ==
=== Subsequent abuse of other illicit drugs === In 1985, [[Gabriel G. Nahas]] published ''Keep Off the Grass'', which stated that "[the] biochemical changes induced by marijuana in the brain result in drug-seeking, drug taking behavior, which in many instances will lead the user to experiment with other pleasurable substances. The risk of progression from marijuana to cocaine to heroin is now well documented."<ref>{{cite book|last=Nahas|first=Gabriel|authorlink=Gabriel G. Nahas|title=Keep off the Grass|publisher=P.S. Eriksson|year=1985|isbn=978-0-8397-4384-2}}</ref>
In 1995, [[The Partnership for a Drug-Free America|Partnership for a Drug-Free America]] with support from the [[National Institute on Drug Abuse]] (NIDA) and the White House Office of Drug Control Policy launched a campaign against cannabis use citing a [[Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse]] (CASA) report, which claimed that cannabis users are 85 times more likely than non-cannabis users to try cocaine.<ref name=ag>{{cite web|url=http://www.drcnet.org/pubs/guide/06-95/gateway.html|title=Marijuana's Gateway Myth|website=drcnet.org|publisher=The Activist Guide|accessdate=2006-03-26}}</ref> However, an article published in ''The Activist Guide'' by John Morgan and Lynn Zimmer entitled "Marijuana's Gateway Myth", claims CASA's statistic is false. The article states:<ref name="ag" /><!---none of these people NOR the book have articles and are therefore not notable. There must be a better reference someplace. [[WP:NN]] people should NOT be in the article by name since they don't have notability--->
{{quote|The high risk-factor obtained is a product not of the fact that so many marijuana users use cocaine but that so many cocaine users used marijuana previously. It is hardly a revelation that people who use one of the least popular drugs are likely to use the more popular ones — not only marijuana, but also alcohol and tobacco cigarettes. The obvious statistic not publicized by CASA is that most marijuana users — 83 percent — never use cocaine.}}
Multiple opponents of cannabis decriminalization have claimed increased cannabis use results in increased abuse of other illicit drugs.<ref name="msnbc1" /><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.theindiancatholic.com/newsread.asp?nid=7768 |publisher= [[Zenit News Agency]] |website= theindiancatholic.com |date=2007-06-03 |accessdate= 2007-06-10|title=Light Drugs, Heavy Consequences}}</ref> However, multiple studies have found no evidence of a correlation between cannabis use and the subsequent abuse of other illicit drugs.
In 1997, the Connecticut Law Revision Commission examined states that had decriminalized cannabis and found decriminalizing small amounts of cannabis has no effect on subsequent use of alcohol or "harder" illicit drugs. The study recommended [[Connecticut]] reduce cannabis possession of one ounce or less for adults age 21 and over to a civil fine.<ref name="clr">{{cite web|url=http://www.cga.ct.gov/lrc/drugpolicy/drugpolicyrpt2.htm#SecD7|title=Connecticut Law Revision Commission Drug Policy Report - Part 1|publisher=Connecticut Law Revision Commission|accessdate=2007-03-26|date=1997-01-21}}</ref>
In 1999, a study by the Division of Neuroscience and Behavioral Health at the [[Institute of Medicine]] entitled "Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing the Science Base", found no evidence of a link between cannabis use and the subsequent abuse of other illicit drugs on the basis of its particular physiological effect.<ref name=IOM>{{cite web|url=http://books.nap.edu/readingroom/books/marimed/notice.html|title=Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing the Science Base|publisher=[[National Academies Press]]|year=1999|accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref>
In December 2002, a study by [[RAND]] investigating whether cannabis use results in the subsequent use of [[cocaine]] and [[heroin]] was published in the British Journal of Addiction. The researchers created a mathematical model simulating adolescent drug use. National rates of cannabis and hard drug use in the model matched survey data collected from representative samples of youths from across the United States; the model produced patterns of drug use and abuse. The study stated:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rand.org/news/press.02/gateway.html |publisher=[[RAND]] |date=2002-12-02 |accessdate=2007-06-10 |title=RAND Study Casts Doubt on Claims that Marijuana Acts as "Gateway" to the Use of Cocaine and Heroin. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061104124529/https://www.rand.org/news/press.02/gateway.html |archivedate=2006-11-04 |df= }}</ref>
{{quote|The people who are predisposed to use drugs and have the opportunity to use drugs are more likely than others to use both marijuana and harder drugs ... Marijuana typically comes first because it is more available. Once we incorporated these facts into our mathematical model of adolescent drug use, we could explain all of the drug use associations that have been cited as evidence of marijuana's gateway effect ... We've shown that the marijuana gateway effect is not the best explanation for the link between marijuana use and the use of harder drugs.}}
In 2004, a study by Craig Reinarman, Peter D. A. Cohen, and Hendrien L. Kaal entitled "The Limited Relevance of Drug Policy: Cannabis in Amsterdam and in San Francisco", was published in the [[American Journal of Public Health]]. The study found no evidence that the decriminalization of cannabis leads to subsequent abuse of other illicit drugs. The study also found the mean age at onset of cannabis use and the mean age of cannabis users are both higher in Amsterdam than in San Francisco.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jennifer McNulty|title=Dutch drug policies do not increase marijuana use, first rigorous comparative study finds|url=http://www.ucsc.edu/currents/03-04/05-03/drug_study.html|website=currents.ucsc.edu|publisher=UC Santa Cruz Currants|date=2004-05-03|accessdate=2007-03-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311002157/http://www.ucsc.edu/currents/03-04/05-03/drug_study.html|archivedate=2007-03-11|df=}}</ref><ref name="ajph">{{Cite journal|url=http://www.ajph.org/cgi/reprint/94/5/836.pdf|title=The Limited Relevance of Drug Policy: Cannabis in Amsterdam and in San Francisco|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=94|issue=5|pages=836–842|year=2004|accessdate=2007-03-20|doi=10.2105/AJPH.94.5.836|pmc=1448346|last1=Reinarman|first1=Craig|last2=Cohen|first2=Peter D. A.|last3=Kaal|first3=Hendrien L.}}</ref>
In 2006, the [[Karolinska Institute]] in Sweden used twelve rats to examine how adolescent use of cannabis affects subsequent abuse of other illicit drugs. The study gave six of the twelve "teenage" rats a small dose of [[Tetrahydrocannabinol|THC]], reportedly equivalent to one joint smoked by a human, every three days. The rats were allowed to administer [[heroin]] by pushing a lever and the study found the rats given THC took larger doses of heroin. The institute examined the brain cells in the rats and found THC alters the opioid system that is associated with positive emotions, which lessens the effects of [[opiate]]s on rat's brain and thus causes them to use more heroin.<ref>{{cite news|title=Why teenagers should steer clear of cannabis|date=2006-07-05|accessdate=2007-05-12|last=Vince|first=Gaia|publisher=New Scientist|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn9488}}</ref> Paul Armentano, policy analyst for [[National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (United States)|NORML]], claimed because the rats were given THC at the young age of 28 days, it is impossible to extrapolate the results of this study to humans.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/column?oid=oid%3A416164|title=Reefer Madness|first=Jordan|last=Smith|date=2006-11-03|accessdate=2007-05-13|publisher=The Austin Chronicle}}</ref>
In December 2006, a 12-year gateway drug hypothesis study on 214 boys from ages 10–12 by the [[American Psychiatric Association]] was published in the [[American Journal of Psychiatry]]. The study concluded adolescents who used cannabis prior to using other drugs, including alcohol and tobacco, were no more likely to develop a substance abuse disorder than subjects in the study who did not use cannabis prior to using other drugs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norml.org/index.cfm?Group_ID=7118|publisher=[[National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (United States)|NORML]]|date=2006-12-07|title=Marijuana Use Per Se Not a 'Gateway' To Illicit Drug Use, Study Says|accessdate=2007-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/content/abstract/163/12/2134|accessdate= 2007-06-09|title=Predictors of Marijuana Use in Adolescents Before and After Licit Drug Use: Examination of the Gateway Hypothesis|journal=American Journal of Psychiatry|volume = 163|issue= 12|pages= 2134–2140|date=December 2006|doi=10.1176/ajp.2006.163.12.2134|pmid= 17151165|last1=Tarter|first1=Ralph E.|last2=Vanyukov|first2=Michael|last3=Kirisci|first3=Levent|last4=Reynolds|first4=Maureen|last5=Clark|first5=Duncan B.}}</ref>
In September 2010, a study from the [[University of New Hampshire]] examined survey data from 1,286 young adults who had attended [[Miami-Dade County Public Schools]] in the 1990s and found the association between teenage cannabis use and other illicit drug abuse by young adults was significantly diminished after controlling for other factors, such as unemployment. They found that after young adults reach age 21, the gateway effect subsides entirely.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/09/100902073507.htm|publisher=[[Science Daily]]|date=2010-09-02|title=Risk of Marijuana's 'Gateway Effect' Overblown, New Research Shows|accessdate=2010-12-24}}</ref>
=== Increased crime === The [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] (DEA) has claimed that cannabis leads to increased crime in the unsourced pamphlet entitled "Speaking Out Against Drug Legalization"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/dea/demand/speakout/09so.htm|title=Fact 9: Europe's More Liberal Drug Policies Are Not the Right Model for America|publisher=[[Drug Enforcement Administration]]|accessdate=2007-04-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210122959/http://www.usdoj.gov/dea/demand/speakout/09so.htm|archivedate=2007-02-10|df=}}</ref>
Studies have found no evidence of a link between cannabis usage and an increase in crime, but rather have found cannabis may decrease criminal behavior when under the influence.<ref name=nixonreport/><ref name=bbc1>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/6484653.stm|title=Is cannabis really a killer?|first=Max|last=Daly|date=2007-03-23|accessdate=2007-04-17|publisher=BBC}}</ref> In 1973, a report by the [[National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse]] entitled "Marijuana: A Signal of Misunderstanding" found marijuana does not cause violent or aggressive behavior, but rather "marijuana was usually found to inhibit the expression of aggressive impulses by pacifying the user, interfering with muscular coordination, reducing psychomotor activities and generally producing states of drowsiness lethargy, timidity and passivity."<ref name=nixonreport /><ref name=bbc1 />
In 2001, a report by David Boyum and [[Mark A.R. Kleiman]] entitled "Substance Abuse Policy from a Crime-Control Perspective" found the "high" from cannabis is unlikely to trigger violence and concluded:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucla.edu/faculty/kleiman/subabus.pdf|title=Substance Abuse Policy from a Crime-Control Perspective|author1=Boyum, David A.|author2=Mark A.R. Kleiman|year=2001|accessdate=2007-06-07 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150513041705/http://www.ucla.edu/faculty/kleiman/subabus.pdf|archivedate=2015-05-13 }}</ref>
{{quote|Making marijuana legally available to adults on more or less the same terms as alcohol would tend to reduce crime, certainly by greatly shrinking the illicit market and possibly by reducing alcohol consumption via substitution if smoking marijuana acts, on balance, as a substitute for drinking alcohol rather than a complement to it since drinking seems to have a greater tendency to unleash aggression than does cannabis use.}}
In 2004, a study by Scott Bates from the Boreal Economic Analysis & Research center entitled "The Economic Implications of Marijuana Legalization in Alaska", was prepared for Alaskans for Rights & Revenues. The study found there was no link between cannabis use and criminal behavior.<ref name="prohibcosts" />
A 2014 study published in [[PLoS ONE]] found that not only did the legalization of [[Medical cannabis]] did not increase violent crime, but that a 2.4% reduction in homicide and assault was found for each year the law was in effect.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Morris|title=The Effect of Medical Marijuana Laws on Crime: Evidence from State Panel Data, 1990-2006|journal=PLoS ONE|date=March 26, 2014|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0092816|display-authors=etal|volume=9|issue=3|pages=e92816|pmid=24671103|pmc=3966811}}</ref>
=== Increased cannabis usage === The [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] (DEA) has claimed that cannabis decriminalization will lead to increased cannabis use and addiction in the un-sourced pamphlet entitled "Speaking Out Against Drug Legalization".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/dea/demand/speakout/06so.htm|title=Speaking Out Against Drug Legalization, Fact 6|date=May 2006|publisher=[[Drug Enforcement Administration]]|accessdate=2007-03-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210094634/http://www.usdoj.gov/dea/demand/speakout/06so.htm|archivedate=2007-02-10|df=}}</ref> The pamphlet states in 1979, after 11 states decriminalized private cannabis use, cannabis use among 12th grade students was almost 51 percent and in 1992, when stricter cannabis laws were put in place, the usage rate reduced to 22 percent. The pamphlet also states that when Alaska decriminalized cannabis in 1975, the cannabis use rate among youth eventually rose to twice the national average youth usage rate nationwide; even though the law did not apply to anyone under the age of 19, the pamphlet explains this is why Alaska re-criminalized cannabis in 1990. Save Our Society From Drugs (SOS) has also stated that decriminalizing cannabis will increase usage among teenagers, citing an increase in Alaskan youth cannabis usage when cannabis was decriminalized.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://cbs4denver.com/local/local_story_263172020.html|title=Opponents Take Aim At Marijuana Amendment|publisher=[[CBS]]: Denver|date=2006-09-20|accessdate=2007-04-19 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060920215631/http://cbs4denver.com/local/local_story_263172020.html |archivedate = 2006-09-20}}</ref> However, cannabis use rose in all states in the 1970s, and the DEA does not say whether or not Alaska started out higher than the national average. Following decriminalization, Alaska youth had lower rates of daily use of cannabis than their peers in the rest of the US.<ref name="cedro-uva.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.cedro-uva.org/lib/harrison.cannabis.06.html |title=Marijuana policy and prevalence |publisher=Cedro-uva.org |date= |accessdate=2010-09-15}}</ref>
In 1972, President [[Richard Nixon]] commissioned the [[National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse]] to produce an in-depth report on cannabis. The report, entitled "Marijuana: A Signal of Misunderstanding", reviewed existing cannabis studies and concluded that cannabis does not cause physical addiction.<ref name=nixonreport />
Studies conducted in Oregon, California, and Maine within a few years of decriminalization found little increase in cannabis use, compared to the rest of the country; "The most frequently cited reasons for non-use by respondents was 'not interested,' cited by about 80% of non-users. Only 4% of adults indicated fear of arrest and prosecution or unavailability as factors preventing use."<ref name="cedro-uva.org"/>
In 1997, the Connecticut Law Revision Commission examined states that had decriminalized cannabis and found any increase in cannabis usage was less than the increase in states that have not decriminalized cannabis; furthermore, the commission stated "the largest proportionate increase [of cannabis use] occurred in those states with the most severe penalties." The study recommended [[Connecticut]] reduce cannabis possession of 28.35 grams (one ounce) or less for adults age 21 and over to a civil fine.<ref name="clr" />
In 1999, a study by the Division of Neuroscience and Behavioral Health at the [[Institute of Medicine]] entitled "Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing the Science Base", concluded "there is little evidence that decriminalization of marijuana use necessarily leads to a substantial increase in marijuana use."<ref name=IOM/><!--REF: pg102-->
In 2001, a report by [[Robert MacCoun]] and [[Peter Reuter]] entitled "Evaluating alternative cannabis regimes", was published in the [[British Journal of Psychiatry]]. The report found there was no available evidence cannabis use would increase if cannabis were decriminalized.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bjp.rcpsych.org/cgi/reprint/178/2/123.pdf|title=Evaluating alternative cannabis regimes|website=bjp.rcpsych.org |publisher=British Journal of Psychiatry|year=2001|accessdate=2007-03-31}}</ref>
In 2004, a study entitled "The Limited Relevance of Drug Policy: Cannabis in Amsterdam and in San Francisco", found strict laws against cannabis use have a low impact on usage rates.<ref name="ajph" />
=== Increased safety concerns === Studies conducted following the legalization of cannabis in Washington and Colorado show that driving under the effects of marijuana increases a driver's likelihood of getting in accident by 100% in comparison to sober drivers. They also suggest that increased use will lead to higher workplace accidents, with employees who tested positive for cannabis being 55% more likely to get in an accident, and 85% more likely to get injured on the job.<ref>[http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=124424502&site=ehost-live "Public Health and Safety Issues Remain."] ''USA Today Magazine'', vol. 146, no. 2867, Aug. 2017, p. 12. EBSCO''host''.</ref>
=== Big business === In a ''[[Huffington Post]]'' interview, [[Mark A.R. Kleiman|Mark Kleiman]], the "Pot Czar" of [[Washington (state)|Washington state]], said he was concerned that the [[National Cannabis Industry Association]] would favor profits over public health. He also said that it could become a predatory body like the lobbying arms of the tobacco and alcohol industries. Kleiman said: "The fact that the National Cannabis Industry Association has hired itself a [[K Street (Washington, D.C.)|K Street]] [[Lobbying in the United States|suit [lobbyist]]] is not a good sign."<ref name=huffpo2>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/18/weed-legalization_n_5169750.html | work=Huffington Post | title=7 Things That Could Totally Kill Weed Legalization's Buzz | date=18 April 2014}}</ref>
== Advocacy == Several U.S.-based advocate groups seek to modify the [[drug policy of the United States]] to decriminalize cannabis. These groups include [[Law Enforcement Against Prohibition]], [[Students for Sensible Drug Policy]], [[Drug Policy Alliance|The Drug Policy Alliance]], the [[Marijuana Policy Project]], [[NORML]], [[Coalition for Rescheduling Cannabis]], and [[Americans for Safe Access]]. There are also many individual American cannabis activists, such as [[Jack Herer]], [[Paul Armentano]], [[Edward Forchion]], [[Jon Gettman]], [[Rob Kampia]], and [[Keith Stroup]]; [[Marc Emery]], a well-known Canadian activist, has supported cannabis activism in the U.S. among other countries by donating money earned from ''[[Cannabis Culture magazine|Cannabis Culture]]'' magazine and Emeryseeds.com.
In 1997, the Connecticut Law Revision Commission recommended [[Connecticut]] reduce cannabis possession of one ounce or less for adults age 21 and over to a civil fine.<ref name=clr /> In 2001, the [[New Mexico]] state-commissioned Drug Policy Advisory Group stated that decriminalizing cannabis "will result in greater availability of resources to respond to more serious crimes without any increased risks to public safety."<ref name=nm />
A few places in [[California]] have been advocating cannabis decriminalization. On November 3, 2004, [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] passed Proposition Z, which makes "adult recreational marijuana use, cultivation and sales the lowest [city] law enforcement priority."<ref>{{cite web |url = http://journalism.berkeley.edu/projects/election2004/archives/2004/11/proposition_z_w.html |title = Election 2004: Oakland Marijuana Measure in the Bag |publisher = journalism.berkeley.edu |accessdate = 2008-07-07 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080605031828/http://journalism.berkeley.edu/projects/election2004/archives/2004/11/proposition_z_w.html |archivedate = 2008-06-05 |df = }}</ref> The proposition states the city of Oakland must advocate to the state of California to adopt laws to regulate and tax cannabis.<ref name="oakland_prop_z">{{cite web|url= http://www.smartvoter.org/2004/11/02/ca/alm/meas/Z/ |website=smartvoter.org|publisher=Smart Voter|title=Measure Z: Marijuana Law Enforcement - Alameda County, CA|accessdate=2006-12-24}}</ref> On November 7, 2006, [[Santa Cruz, California|Santa Cruz]] passed [[Measure K 2006|Measure K]], which made cannabis the lowest priority for city law enforcement. The measure requests the Santa Cruz City Clerk send letters annually to [[U.S. state|state]] and [[Federal government of the United States|federal]] representatives advocating reform of cannabis laws.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sensiblesantacruz.org/initiative.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070106172530/http://www.sensiblesantacruz.org/initiative.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-01-06 |title=Measure K - Lowest Law Enforcement Priority Initiative: FAQ |website=sensiblesantacruz.org |publisher=Santa Cruz Citizens for Sensible Marijuana Policy |accessdate=2007-06-11 |df= }}</ref> On June 5, 2007, [[Mendocino County, California|Mendocino County]] Board of Supervisors voted 4-1 to send a letter in support of the legalization, regulation, and taxation of cannabis to [[U.S. state|state]] and [[Federal government of the United States|federal]] legislators, and the [[President of United States]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukiahdailyjournal.com/ci_6074058|title=Marijuana legalization letter OK'd|first=Katie|last=Mintz|date=2007-06-06|accessdate=2007-06-11|publisher=Ukiah Daily Journal}}</ref>
[[Ron Paul]], a former Texas Congressman and 2008 Presidential Candidate, stated at a rally in response to a question by a medical cannabis patient that he would "never use the federal government to force the law against anybody using marijuana."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AegRynzxQJA|title=Ron Paul on marijuana laws|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=2008-01-02}}</ref> In his book, ''[[The Revolution: A Manifesto]]'' he writes, "Regardless of where one stands on the broader drug war, we should all be able to agree on the subject of medical marijuana. Here, the use of an otherwise prohibited substance has been found to relieve unbearable suffering in countless patients. How can we fail to support liberty and individual responsibility in such a clear cut case? What harm does it do to anyone else to allow fellow human beings in pain to find the relief they need?"<ref>{{cite book|title=The Revolution: A Manifesto|publisher=Grand Central Publishing}}</ref> He is also the cosponsor of the [[Personal Use of Marijuana by Responsible Adults Act of 2008]].
[[Mike Gravel]], a former [[United States Senate|U.S. senator]] from Alaska and [[Mike Gravel presidential campaign, 2008|2008 presidential candidate]], responded to a caller on a [[C-SPAN]] program asking about cannabis and the drug war, he stated "That one is real simple, I would legalize marijuana. You should be able to buy that at a liquor store."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1KyFRyxZp-s|title=Part 2 - Mike Gravel - The Issues that Matter - Washington Journal.|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=2007-06-13}}</ref>
[[Dennis Kucinich]], a [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. representative]] from [[Ohio]] and [[Dennis Kucinich#2008 Presidential campaign|2008 presidential candidate]], has been an advocate of cannabis legalization. During Kucinich's 2004 presidential campaign, the following was posted on Kucinich's official campaign web site.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle-old/316/kucinich.shtml|title=Newsbrief: Campaign Watch -- Kucinich Says Legalize It|date=2003-12-19|accessdate=2007-06-13|website=stopthedrugwar.org}}</ref> {{quote|Most marijuana users do so responsibly, in a safe, recreational context. These people lead normal, productive lives — pursuing careers, raising families and participating in civic life ... A Kucinich administration would reject the current paradigm of 'all use is abuse' in favor of a drug policy that sets reasonable boundaries for marijuana use by establishing guidelines similar to those already in place for alcohol.}}
Some members of religious organizations, even while not necessarily being in favor of marijuana consumption, have also spoken in favor of reform, due to medical reasons, or the social costs of enforcement and incarceration.<ref name=religionnews>{{cite web|url=http://www.religionnews.com/2014/02/03/faith-leaders-wrestle-growing-support-marijuana/ |title=Faith leaders wrestle over growing support for marijuana |publisher=Religion News Service |date=2014-02-03 |author=Sarah Pulliam Bailey |accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref> For instance, Revered Samuel Rodriguez of National Hispanic Christian Leadership Conferences stated that "laws that prohibit marijuana affect the minorities significantly and hence should be reconsidered." Religious groups uphold that marijuana does not harm as much as alcohol does and thus legalizing it for medicinal usage would not be harmful to the economy.<ref name=religionnews/>
In 1974 Dr Robert DuPont began to publicly support decriminalization of cannabis, seeing cannabis as a health problem. But when DuPont left government he changed his mind and declared that "decriminalization is a bad idea".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/drugs/interviews/dupont.html |title=WGBH educational foundation. Interview with Dr. Robert Dupoint |publisher=PBS |date=1970-02-18 |accessdate=2011-04-20}}</ref> Robert DuPont is still an active opponent of decriminalization of cannabis.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/36267223/Why_We_Should_Not_Legalize_Marijuana |title=Robert DuPont: Why We Should Not Legalize Marijuana, CNBS, 20 Apr 2010 |publisher=CNBC |date=2010-04-20 |accessdate=2014-05-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715235629/http://www.cnbc.com/id/36267223/Why_We_Should_Not_Legalize_Marijuana |archive-date=2014-07-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
